fields.note: We base your benefit estimate on current formulas from the Social Security Administration using your age and current income. Your answers are anonymous. Because we do not access or use your Social Security earnings record, your actual benefits may vary from this estimate.
fields.instructions: Enter your information below to see your estimated benefits.
fields.title: Explore how your claiming age affects your Social Security retirement benefits

fields.instructions: Tell us more about yourself for additional tips to make your decision.
fields.title: Consider these five factors

fields.note: (This will not affect your Social Security account or begin an application.)
fields.instructions: Select the age you plan to claim your Social Security retirement benefits.
fields.title: Take your next steps

fields.instructions: Create a my Social Security account to review your expected benefits based on your actual Social Security record. You'll receive an annual reminder to review your benefits. You will also find additional information about your eligibility and other benefits including disability and survivor benefits.
fields.title: final_step_1

fields.instructions: Your retirement income outside of Social Security is an important way to fill the gap between your Social Security benefit and the income that you will need to cover your expenses. You can increase your contributions to your retirement savings plans, or open and contribute to an IRA or myRA plan.
fields.title: final_step_2_under

fields.instructions: If your income, employment, or marital status changes, you may need to reconsider your claiming age. Visit us again!
fields.title: final_step_3

fields.instructions: Was this page helpful in thinking about your claiming age decision?
fields.title: final_step_4

fields.instructions: While you wait to claim your benefits, you can continue growing your savings by making catchup contributions to your existing accounts. You may also be able to open and contribute to an IRA or myRA plan.
fields.title: final_step_2_equal

fields.instructions: While you let your benefits continue to grow, you can keep working if you want. You can also stop working and use a portion of your savings to cover your needs. Learn the rules about withdrawing money from your retirement accounts.
fields.title: final_step_2_over

fields.aside: Claiming at your full retirement age locks in your full monthly benefit.
Claiming at the earliest year locks in a monthly benefit about 30% below your full retirement amount.
Claiming four years early locks in a benefit about 25% below your full amount.
Claiming three years early locks in a benefit about 20% below your full amount.
Claiming two years early locks in a benefit about 13% below your full amount.
Claiming a year early locks in a benefit about 6.7% below your full amount.
Waiting a year to claim boosts your monthly benefit by about 8%.
Waiting two years to claim boosts your monthly benefit by about 16%.
Waiting until 70 gets you the maximum monthly benefit.

fields.title: Claiming Social Security
fields.h1: Claiming Social Security—choices to fit your needs
fields.intro: The age you claim your benefits matters for your lifetime income. We'll help you think through this important decision.

fields.text: Maximum retirement age: Always 70. This is the age at which you will get the maximum possible benefit. You should not claim your benefit after this age.
fields.title: max

fields.text: Early retirement: Any time before your full retirement age. If you claim your benefits before your full retirement age, they will be permanently reduced. The earliest age you can claim your retirement benefit is 62.
fields.title: early

fields.text: Social Security retirement benefits are not designed to be your sole source of retirement income, but waiting even one month will increase your benefits.
fields.title: sole_source

fields.text: We calculate benefit estimates based on the Social Security Administration's Quick Calculator. The SSA uses the date of birth and current income values to build an average lifetime earnings history and calculate benefits. The benefit estimates we provide are only approximations, and are intended solely as a way to show how different claiming dates can affect monthly benefits. Social Security will calculate more accurate benefits estimates based on your actual lifetime earnings if you go to Social Security's sign-up page and create an account.
fields.title: calculations

fields.text: Full retirement age varies between 66 and 67 depending on your date of birth. This is the age at which you will receive your full benefit with no reductions.
fields.title: fra

fields.text: Enter your total work income before taxes and other deductions. If your work income is 0 (zero) because you are now retired or unemployed, enter the income for the last year in which you worked.
fields.title: salary

fields.text: On average, a woman reaching age 65 today will live to age 87, and a man will live to age 84.
fields.title: lifetime

fields.text: If you and your spouse are full retirement age, you can apply for benefits but have the payments suspended. This allows your spouse to file for spousal benefits without affecting your personal benefits. For details, see Social Security's guide.
fields.title: file_and_suspend

fields.text: myRA (my Retirement Account) is a retirement savings program offered by the U.S. Department of Treasury with no minimum contributions, fees, or risky investments, for those without a retirement savings program from their employer.
fields.title: myra

fields.text: If both spouses are full retirement age, you can apply for spousal benefits if you haven't filed before and if your spouse has already filed (regardless of your spouse's suspension status). For details, see Social Security's guide.
fields.title: restricted_application

fields.text: Our tool shows your estimated benefit for nine specific claiming points. However, you can claim at any point between age 62 and 70, and your benefit amount will depend on the specific month that you claim.
fields.title: estimated_benefits

fields.text: Once you reach your full retirement benefits claiming age, you can work and earn as much as you want and your benefits will not be reduced. If you claim before this age and continue to work, your benefits could be temporarily reduced if you earn over a certain limit, but any reductions you receive will be credited back to you once you reach full retirement age.
fields.title: working_longer

fields.text: A type of retirement savings account offered by employers to help their employees save for retirement.
fields.title: 401k

fields.text: Your Social Security benefits could be reduced if you receive federal, state, or local government pensions that are based on work where you did not pay Social Security taxes.
fields.title: pensions

fields.text: IRAs are types of retirement savings plans with special tax incentives. In these plans, your savings equal the contributions that you make to the account plus the gains or losses of your investments.
fields.title: iras

fields.text: Catch-up contributions are additional contributions that individuals who are age 50 or older can make to their 401(k), IRA, or myRA accounts to help them boost their savings as they approach retirement.
fields.title: catchup_contributions

fields.note: The Social Security website is not responding, so we can't estimate your benefits right now. Please try again in a few minutes.
fields.internal_note: for use when SSA doesn't respond, returns bad data or times out
fields.error: SSA's Quick Calculator is not responding

fields.note: We're sorry. Our tool cannot provide an estimate if you not at least 22 years old. Please visit the Social Security Administration's advice page for students and younger workers.
fields.internal_note: SSA Quick Calculator won't work for people younger than 22.

fields.note: We're sorry. We cannot provide an estimate because you are older than Social Security's maximum claiming age. To check your benefits, contact the Social Security Administration or open a my Social Security account.
fields.internal_note: SSA will deliver a benefit for people older than 70, but our tool is not relevant for them.

fields.answer_unsure_a_subhed: Your survivor benefits may help you get a higher retirement benefit.
fields.title: Marriage
fields.answer_no_a_subhed: You can protect the financial security of your surviving spouse.
fields.answer_yes_a: Your decision of when to claim your Social Security could affect the benefits  your spouse will receive after you die. Surviving spouses can keep either their own benefit or choose to keep their spouse's benefit, whichever is higher. If you are married, and are the higher earner in the household, claiming at your full benefit age will ensure your spouse will receive the higher benefit. Talk to your spouse about your claiming options so you can make this important decision together.
fields.question: Are you married?
fields.answer_unsure_a: If your deceased spouse qualified for Social Security, you may qualify for a survivor benefit. You can claim a reduced survivor benefit as early as age 60 or wait until age 70 to get the maximum benefit possible. Your decision about when to start receiving your survivor benefit is independent from your decision of when to start receiving your own retirement benefit. If you expect your own retirement benefit to be higher than your survivor benefit, consider claiming your survivor benefit first. This could help you wait as long as you can to maximize your own retirement benefit. You will only receive one benefit at a time, though.
fields.answer_yes_a_subhed: You can protect the financial security of your surviving spouse.
fields.answer_no_a: If you claim at your full Social Security benefit age or later, you will avoid a reduction in your monthly benefit. In addition, if you choose to wait to claim past your full benefit age until age 70, you can get an increase for every month that you wait. If you are divorced, your former spouse's claiming decision will not affect your benefit, so it should not affect your decision of when to claim.

fields.answer_no_b_subhed: You can maximize your benefits even if you work fewer hours or stop working.
fields.answer_unsure_a_subhed: Consider working in your 60s for an extra boost to your income and savings.
fields.answer_yes_b_subhed: Working in your 60s will help you maximize your income and savings.
fields.title: Sixties
fields.answer_no_a_subhed: You can maximize your benefits even if you work fewer hours or stop working.
fields.answer_yes_b: Your benefits are based on your highest 35 years of earnings. Each year of work can add higher earnings to your record by replacing years with low earnings such as those when you were a student, were unemployed, or took time off to care for someone. When you work and wait to claim until age 70, you can increase your monthly benefit by more than 75 percent! Working in your 60s also gives you more time to save on your own for retirement.
fields.answer_yes_a: Your benefits are based on your highest 35 years of earnings. Each year of work can add higher earnings to your record by replacing years with low earnings such as those when you were a student, were unemployed, or took time off to care for someone. When you work and wait to claim until age 70, you can increase your monthly benefit by more than 75 percent! Working in your 60s also gives you more time to save on your own for retirement.
fields.question: Do you plan to continue working in your 60s?
fields.answer_unsure_b: Working in your 60s may add higher earnings to your record, getting you a higher monthly benefit. Remember, your monthly benefit will be significantly higher when you claim at your full Social Security benefit age or later. If you need to work fewer hours, you could use a portion of your retirement savings such as your 401(k) , Individual Retirement Account (IRA) or myRA account to supplement your income until full retirement age. However, this may not be an option if it eliminates your savings completely.
fields.answer_unsure_a: Working in your 60s may increase your monthly benefit in a few ways. Because your benefits are based on your highest 35 years of earnings, each year of work can add higher earnings to your record by replacing years with low earnings, such as those when you were a student, were unemployed, or took time off. When you claim at your full retirement age, you can increase your monthly benefit by 25 percent or more. Working in your 60s also gives you more time to save on your own for retirement.
fields.answer_unsure_b_subhed: Consider working in your 60s for an extra boost to your income and savings.
fields.answer_yes_a_subhed: Working in your 60s will help you maximize your income and savings.
fields.answer_no_b: You may choose to work fewer hours or stop working in your 60s. If you decide to do so, you could use a portion of your retirement savings such as your 401(k) , Individual Retirement Account (IRA) , or myRA account to supplement your income in your early 60s until you reach your full Social Security benefit claiming age. If you can continue working in your 60s, you may add higher earnings to your record, getting you a higher monthly benefit. Remember, your monthly benefit will be significantly higher when you claim at your full benefit age or later. The age at which you decide to stop working doesn't have to be the same as your claiming age.
fields.answer_no_a: You may choose to work fewer hours or stop working in your 60s. If you decide to do so, you could use a portion of your retirement savings such as your 401(k) , Individual Retirement Account (IRA) , or myRA account to supplement your income in your early 60s until you reach your full Social Security benefit claiming age. If you can continue working in your 60s, you may add higher earnings to your record, getting you a higher monthly benefit. Remember, your monthly benefit will be significantly higher when you claim at your full benefit age or later. The age at which you decide to stop working doesn't have to be the same as your claiming age.

fields.answer_no_b_subhed: Many people find retirement is more expensive than expected.
fields.answer_unsure_a_subhed: You can protect your lifestyle by planning ahead.
fields.title: Expenses
fields.answer_no_a_subhed: Many people find retirement is more expensive than expected.
fields.answer_yes_b: If you're planning an active retirement or carry a mortgage or other debt, your first few years in retirement may be more expensive than you expect. Some regular expenses like your out-of-pocket health care costs will likely increase as you get older. You can protect your retirement lifestyle by reducing your largest expenses. You can also increase your regular income by claiming at your full Social Security benefit age or later. If you claim earlier, your monthly benefit could be reduced by as much as 30 percent.
fields.answer_yes_a: If you're planning an active retirement or carry a mortgage or other debt, your first few years in retirement may be more expensive than you expect. Some regular expenses like your out-of-pocket health care costs will likely increase as you get older. You can protect your retirement lifestyle by reducing your largest expenses. You can also increase your regular income by claiming at your full Social Security benefit age or later. If you claim earlier, your monthly benefit could be reduced by as much as 30 percent.
fields.question: Will your expenses decrease after you retire?
fields.answer_unsure_b: Future expenses are difficult to predict. Some regular expenses like out-of-pocket health care costs will likely increase as you get older. You can protect your retirement lifestyle by reducing your largest expenses. Consider downsizing or paying off your mortgage before you retire. You can also increase your regular income by claiming at your full Social Security benefit age or later. If you claim earlier, your monthly benefit could be reduced by as much as 30 percent.
fields.answer_unsure_a: Future expenses are difficult to predict. Some regular expenses like out-of-pocket health care costs will likely increase as you get older. You can protect your retirement lifestyle by reducing your largest expenses. Consider downsizing or paying off your mortgage before you retire. You can also increase your regular income by claiming at your full Social Security benefit age or later. If you claim earlier, your monthly benefit could be reduced by as much as 30 percent.
fields.answer_unsure_b_subhed: You can protect your lifestyle by planning ahead.
fields.answer_no_b: Future expenses are difficult to predict. Some regular expenses like out-of-pocket health care costs will likely increase as you get older. You can protect your retirement lifestyle by reducing your largest expenses. Consider downsizing or paying off your mortgage before you retire. You can also increase your regular income by claiming at your full Social Security benefit age or later. If you claim earlier, your monthly benefit could be reduced by as much as 30 percent.
fields.answer_no_a: Future expenses are difficult to predict. Some regular expenses like out-of-pocket health care costs will likely increase as you get older. You can protect your retirement lifestyle by reducing your largest expenses. Consider downsizing or paying off your mortgage before you retire. You can also increase your regular income by claiming at your full Social Security benefit age or later. If you claim earlier, your monthly benefit could be reduced by as much as 30 percent.

fields.answer_no_b_subhed: It's never too late to start saving!
fields.answer_unsure_a_subhed: There are many ways to plan for a secure retirement outside of Social Security.
fields.answer_yes_b_subhed: You have an opportunity to continue growing your money.
fields.title: Income
fields.answer_no_a_subhed: It's a perfect time to start saving.
fields.answer_yes_b: If you can, get the highest monthly Social Security benefit possible by claiming at your full Social Security benefit age or later. If you claim before your full retirement age, your monthly benefit could be permanently reduced by as much as 30 percent. Also, take advantage of catch-up contributions to your 401(k) , Individual Retirement Account (IRA) , or myRA after age 50. Lastly, avoid losing your retirement savings to unnecessary tax penalties. If you withdraw your 401(k), IRA, or myRA savings before age 59½, you will likely face an early withdrawal penalty.
fields.answer_yes_a: Social Security won't replace all of your pre-retirement income . On average, Social Security replaces 40 percent of a worker's income. That means your retirement savings, pension , 401(k) , Individual Retirement Account (IRA) , or myRA will need to fill the gap. Claiming at your full Social Security benefit age or later (up to age 70) can minimize this gap and maximize your monthly benefit. If you claim before your full retirement age, your monthly benefit could be reduced by as much as 30 percent.
fields.question: Do you expect to have additional sources of retirement income beyond Social Security?
fields.answer_unsure_b: You may be able to save through your employer's retirement plan, an Individual Retirement Account (IRA) , or myRA . Maximize an employer match if one is offered. This will help you grow your retirement savings faster. You can also make additional contributions to these accounts called catch-up contributions . Your decision about when to claim your Social Security benefits is especially important if you cannot or did not save as much as you would like. When you claim at your full Social Security benefit age or later, you avoid a reduction in your monthly benefit. You will also get increases for every month that you wait to claim past your full benefit age until age 70.
fields.answer_unsure_a: You may be able to save through your employer's 401(k) , an Individual Retirement Account (IRA) , or myRA . Maximize an employer match if one is offered. Some employers match some of the money you put in your 401(k) retirement plan, helping you grow your retirement savings faster. Your decision about when to claim your Social Security benefits is especially important if you cannot or did not save as much as you would like. When you claim at your full Social Security benefit age or later, you avoid a reduction in your monthly benefit. You will also get increases for every month that you wait to claim past your full benefit age until age 70.
fields.answer_unsure_b_subhed: It's never too late to start saving.
fields.answer_yes_a_subhed: Continue saving in the coming years.
fields.answer_no_b: You could save through your employer's 401(k) , an Individual Retirement Account (IRA) , or myRA . Make sure to maximize an employer match if one is offered. Some employers match some of the money you put in your 401(k) plan which helps to grow your retirement savings faster. You can also make additional contributions to these accounts called catch-up contributions . If you expect Social Security to be your only source of income, you can still make the most out of it by waiting to claim at your full Social Security benefit age or later. When you claim before your full retirement age, your monthly benefit could be reduced by as much as 30 percent.
fields.answer_no_a: You could save through your employer's 401(k) , an Individual Retirement Account (IRA) , or myRA to fill the gap. Maximize an employer match if one is offered. Some employers match the money you put in your 401(k) plan which helps to grow your retirement savings. Even if you're unable to save as much as you'd like, your small savings today will grow over time and can become extra income or emergency savings in the future. If you expect Social Security to be your only source of income, you can still make the most out of it by claiming at your full Social Security benefit age or later. If you claim before your full retirement age, your monthly benefit could be reduced by as much as 30 percent. On the other hand, you can get extra increases for every month that you wait to claim past your full benefit age until age 70.

fields.answer_unsure_a_subhed: There's a good chance that you'll live into your 80s and beyond.
fields.title: Long life
fields.answer_no_a_subhed: Claiming at your full benefit age could still make sense for you.
fields.answer_yes_a: Because Social Security provides guaranteed income for life, it's especially valuable to you when you reach age 80 and beyond. Claiming benefits at your full Social Security benefit age or later could be a good way to secure your monthly income during your later years.  Your benefit increases the longer you wait to claim, up to age 70, and is adjusted annually with the cost of living. If you live into your 80s but claim at age 62 instead of your full retirement age or later, your total lifetime benefits will be lower by thousands of dollars.
fields.question: Do you expect to live a long life?
fields.answer_unsure_a: We understand it's difficult to make predictions. You may want to plan for the possibility that you (or your spouse) may live a long life. On average, a woman reaching age 65 today will live to age 87, and a man will live to age 84. Claiming benefits at your full Social Security benefit age or later could be a good way to secure your monthly income during your later years. Your monthly benefit increases the longer you wait to claim, up to age 70, and is adjusted annually with the cost of living. If you live into your 80s but claim at age 62 instead of your full retirement age or later, your total lifetime benefits will be lower by thousands of dollars.
fields.answer_yes_a_subhed: Protect yourself from outliving your money.
fields.answer_no_a: We understand it's difficult to make predictions. You may want to plan for the possibility that you (or your spouse) may live a long life. On average, a woman reaching age 65 today will live to age 87, and a man will live to age 84. Waiting to claim as long as you can could still make sense for you if you are married, are the higher earner in the household, and want your surviving spouse to keep the highest monthly benefit after you die. Remember, you can claim at any point between age 62 and 70. Each additional month that you wait to claim gives you a permanent increase in your monthly benefit which becomes more valuable as you age.
